summary: noun / retail & radio practice. A record manufactured for free distribution.
definition: **noun / retail & radio practice.** A record manufactured for free distribution to radio DJs, reviewers, or retail stores, typically stamped or labeled **"Promotional Copy — Not For Sale"** or **"For Radio Play Only"**. Emerged in the late 1940s as labels sought airplay exposure without retail sales tracking. Promos often feature unique characteristics: white labels with typed info, drill holes through the center, gold-stamped covers, or clipped corners. Some contain rare mono mixes, alternate takes, or hot-cut lacquers with louder grooves optimized for radio broadcast. Major labels pressed thousands for album campaigns, while smaller operations hand-stamped retail copies. The practice peaked in the 1960s-80s when radio programming drove sales. Modern promos are largely digital, making vinyl specimens highly collectible—especially first pressings with unique mixes. Value varies wildly: common promos trade near standard copies, while rare variants (Beatles mono promos, jazz white labels) command premiums. Authenticity matters; counterfeit promo stamps exist.
etymology: Shortened from "promotional copy," adopted by record labels in the late 1940s as radio became the primary vehicle for music marketing and airplay tracking systems required non-sale inventory designation.
